Design of an emotional and social interaction paradigm for the animation of 3D characters: the case of a therapy for brain injured people (the mirror neuron paradigm)

Design of an emotional and social interaction paradigm for the animation of 3D characters: the case of a therapy for brain injured people (the mirror neuron paradigm)

  • María Lucila Morales-Rodriguez1 &
  • Bernard Pavard1 

Virtual Reality volume 11, pages175–184(2007)Cite this article

  • 257 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

We propose an emotional and social interaction paradigm for the behavioural animation of virtual characters. Our research focuses on the production of verbal and paraverbal interactions between a human and a virtual character in the context of virtual therapy. The aim of this project is to assess virtual therapies for the rehabilitation of people with brain injuries caused by cerebral vascular accidents. The therapeutic paradigm is based on the neuroscience concept of “mirror neurones” which emphasise the perceptual side in the process of recovering neural damage. In our paradigm, the patient interacts with a virtual therapist (embodied autonomous agent) that guides and encourages him in order to fulfil the drills. Furthermore and following the “mirror neurone paradigm”, the patient can only see his virtual hands (which are handicapped). The virtual platform provides the patient with a vision of his hands undertaking a movement that he cannot perform. Doing so, we expect that the perception of this virtual movement may improve the recuperation (mirror neurone paradigm). In this paper, we also introduce the notion of an “intelligent emotional character” to produce a sense of social as well as emotional immersion in order to improve the interaction between the patient and the virtual therapist. We discuss the role of emotional interaction in the context of virtual social interaction and in particular its reflexive dimension. Finally, we present an architecture for the animation of virtual characters based on a multidisciplinary approach to model the emotional and social interaction.

Introduction

Social interactions in virtual worlds are becoming a new trend in fields such as gaming, education and therapy. Concerning therapy, virtual reality makes it possible to create an interactive environment, where the drills could be controlled, quantified and modulated, reinforcing the cognitive abilities of the patient and minimising the cost of rehabilitation.

The literature concerning virtual characters emphasises the fact that the implementation of credible characters requires a multidisciplinary approach which takes into account the psychological, sociological and philosophical dimensions of the problem [1, 2]. We strongly agree with this statement and the aim of this paper will be to propose an emotional and social interaction paradigm for the behavioural animation of virtual characters in the context of virtual therapy.

The goal of this work is to produce a sense of social and emotional immersion for a patient that is in interaction with a virtual therapist who is driving the therapeutic drills. The research focuses on the problem of generating interaction driven by meaningful intentions and their associated verbal and paraverbal expressions.

The research is based on the paradigm developed by El Jed et al. [3] related to the potential of 3D virtual reality for the design of complex cooperative systems. Our objective is to put the user in a situation close to physical reality (with respect to the objects and dynamics of the environment) as well as the social environment (compliance with the rules of conversation and indicators of the emotional state of the characters).

The theoretical background of our approach is related to the concept of situated interaction, which emphasises the role of the context (external artefacts as well as interpersonal history) in behaviour interpretation and the fact that the meaningful part of the communication is co-constructed by the actors during the ongoing interaction. We tried to make this concept operational in terms of the quality of the coupling between actors as well between actors and their environment [4].

The paper is structured as follows. Sections 2–4 are related to the neuroscience concepts that support the therapeutic research, the purpose of the project and the application of virtual reality in this area, respectively. Sections 5–8 cover the description of the social and cognitive model as well as the development of the virtual platform. Section 9 concludes the paper.

Cerebral vascular accidents and the mirror neuron paradigm

A stroke or cerebral vascular accident (CVA) is a temporary or permanent loss of functioning brain tissue caused by an interruption in the cerebral blood supply [5].

The consequences of a stroke depend upon which areas of the brain are affected. After a stroke, many patients express their emotions to a much greater extent than they did before their illness. Many of them have some paralysis. A stroke may also affect their ability to process language, reading, articulating or even their ability to swallow [5].

Cerebral vascular accidents are, in the western countries, the third cause of mortality and a major cause of handicap. Studies in this field show that 80% of people having had a CVA recover the ability to walk, whereas only 5–20% recover a completely functional upper limb. These kinds of patients are frequently depressed and have difficulties to evaluate their performance [6].

The aim of INSERMFootnote 1 is to assess a therapeutic paradigm based on the neuroscience notion of “mirror neurons” in order to induce a cerebral plasticity and increase the patient’s motor recovery.

The discovery of mirror neurons in the frontal lobes of the macaque monkey brain is considered to be one of the most important findings in neuroscience in the last decade [7]. Mirror neurons are premotor neurons that fire when the monkey performs object-directed actions (grasping, tearing, manipulating, holding) but also when the animal observes somebody else (monkeys or humans) performing the same class of actions. Neurons with similar properties were later discovered in a sector of the posterior parietal cortex reciprocally connected with area F5 of the inferior frontal cortex and areas PF/PFG of the inferior parietal cortex [8–11].

The mirror neuron structures are likely to be the key to the functional recovery of CVA patients, considering that the perception of movements could help to activate gradually the motor circuits that are associated with the movement production [6].

Rehabilitation of the active extension of the wrist for CVA brain injured people

The efficiency of the rehabilitation for brain injured people is related to three main factors: an early treatment, exercises adapted to each patient, and an intensive repetition of the movements [6, 12]. The emotional nature of the relationship between the patient and the therapist is also a factor that can modulate the efficiency of the therapy.

It is known that the intensive repetition of movements in their habitual environment and the patient’s willingness to practice with the deficient member increases the motor recovery and improves the cerebral plasticity. There are also some arguments in favour of the role of the sensorial information (visual perception of the movement) in motor recovery [6, 13]. The recovery, based on the visual perception of the movement, is produced through the sensor–motor transformation of the cerebral circuits that is associated with the movement production. This is in line with the idea expressed in the mirror neuron paradigm [6].

The purpose of INSERM’s project is to integrate the mirror neuron paradigm in a virtual reality rehabilitation protocol to the active extension of the wrist to CVA brain injured people and to evaluate the role of the improved visual feedback during the voluntary production of the movement. With “improved” feedback, the patient sees his wrist doing better than his real performance. Doing so, he will activate the coupling between the perceptive and motor circuits and improve the recovery (mirror neurone hypothesis).

This “improved” protocol will be evaluated on a therapy session. The results will be compared with another “controlled” therapy session with real feedback in real time. The evaluation of the sessions will rest on a criterion of functional imagery and motor performances.

Virtual reality makes it possible to create an “improved” virtual situation that makes the patient believe that he has slightly progressed in order to test the importance of the visual information and to stimulate his participation in the rehabilitation program.

Virtual reality and rehabilitation

Virtual reality offers us the opportunity to bring the complexity of the physical world into the controlled environment of a laboratory and makes it possible to create an interactive environment, where the therapeutic drills could be controlled, quantified and modulated in order to improve the rehabilitation process for the patient.

Virtual reality technology has been used for several decades for a variety of psychosocial applications. The most frequent usage in this domain is in creating 3D simulations of reality that can be explored by patients under the supervision of a therapist. Such applications frequently use a totally immersive VR system like head mounted display (HMD) where the patient sees only the computer-generated image and the rest of the physical world is blocked from their view [14, 15].

The applications of virtual reality for brain injured people caused by CVA are numerous: care of cognitive disorders, such as the attention disorders or the executive functions, motor rehabilitation, coordination work and increase in the force and speed of movement execution. Since the early 1990s there has been an increase in the number of laboratories and clinics promoting the use of virtual technologies for physical rehabilitation. Usually, the motivation for developing such applications is the need to reproduce at a lesser cost a virtual environment that is close to the real one and less distractive [6, 12–14].

Although there is a lot of potential for the use of immersive virtual reality environments in clinical applications, there are problems which could limit their ultimate usability. Some users have experienced side-effects during and after exposure to hardware devices of virtual reality environments. The symptoms include ocular problems, nausea, disorientation and balance disturbances. Susceptibility to side-effects can be affected by age, ethnicity, experience, gender and physical fitness, as well as the characteristics of the display, the virtual environment and the tasks [15, 16]. But virtual reality cannot merely be reduced to a hardware system; there is an inclusive relationship between the participant and the virtual environment that constitutes an interface of communication. The interactivity between the participant and the virtual environment could affect their subjective experience and stresses the active role of the participant in the virtual session and their immersion. To achieve an optimal experience, the concept of social presence plays a key role in the immersion linked to an emotional experience [17–19].

We consider that one way to produce a sense of immersion associated to an emotional and social experience is to use non-intrusive interfaces to capture the movement and the interaction with a virtual character that expresses a social and emotional behaviour. This kind of social immersion could stimulate the participation of the patient during the rehabilitation therapy. This is particularly important in post-CVA patients because they are frequently depressed and have difficulties in evaluating their performances.

Immersion in virtual worlds

Most of the applications and research in immersive virtual reality see immersion as a physical experience produced by technological devices capable of enabling an illusion that is inclusive, extensive, surrounding and vivid. Many see the sense of presence as a result of the immersion in a virtual environment [18, 20].

In most cases the term presence is used to describe the subjective feelings of such experience. The traditional views of the term presence are usually defined as the “sense of being there” or the “perceptual illusion of non-mediation” [18, 21]. Few researches try to evoke and replicate reactions and emotions that occur in the real experiences. In an ecological view of presence, Mantovani and Riva [22, 23] proposed a socio-cultural focus of presence, where experiencing presence and telepresence does not depend so much on the reproduction of the physical reality as on the capacity of simulation to produce a context in which social actors may communicate and cooperate.

In the domain of virtual character, the researches focus more on the concept of immersion than on the one of presence. Particularly in video games several kinds of immersion has been proposed [24]: tactical immersion is an “immersion in the moment-by-moment act of playing the game”. It is produced when the player is on the lookout for information and ready to answer instinctively (‘being in the groove’); strategic immersion is a “cerebral kind of involvement with the game” with the player seeking a path to victory, or at least trying to optimise a situation; finally, there is narrative immersion which is much the same as it is in books or movies. A player becomes immersed in a narrative when he or she starts to care about the characters and wants to know how the story is going to end.

Immersion by social and emotional interaction

We will emphasise the role of the social interaction and its related feeling that we will call social immersion. This kind of immersion is strictly connected with the view of presence proposed by Mantovani and Riva [22, 23]. This social immersion has the characteristic of putting the user of the virtual world into a state where the emotional dimension strongly intervenes. To be able to produce such type of immersion, the virtual character must ideally be able to follow several requirements: credibility of emotional expressions (their adequacy compared to the situation, within the context); reflexivity of the interaction (the character must, in real time, have the capacity to adjust simultaneously their facial and bodily emotional expressions) and indexicality (the gestural expressions must depend closely on the references that the user makes to the external world) [25].

We consider that the human-like interactive social style through nonverbal expressions, social behaviours and empathy expressions are key factors in the generation of social and emotional immersion. For this reason it is important that the characters with which the user interacts, expressess emotional and social behaviours in their interaction.

Production of social and emotional interaction

The production of social and emotional interaction requires that the interlocutors understand verbal, paraverbal and body expressions.

Our model focuses on the production of such expressions in the context of the ongoing activity. The architecture for the animation of virtual characters (described in Sect. 8) integrates these characteristics to produce (1) acts of communication that transmit intentions and (2) animations that characterise emotional expressions and social interactions rules.

This creates an intelligent emotional character based on an emotional and social interaction paradigm.

Design of an emotional character

We define an intelligent emotional character as a character which has the capability to modify their emotional states in relation to the context (evaluation of actions and attitudes of his interlocutor).

In our work, the production and interpretation of emotional states is at the core of the behavioural model; this process defines the dynamics of the nonverbal behaviour that expresses social and emotional interactions in a situated face-to-face communication. In addition, it has an influence in the selection of objectives and intentions of the communications acts of it dialogue.

A multidisciplinary approach

In the design of the behavioural model we focused mostly on theories related to social interaction, expression of emotions and personality. As show in Fig. 1, we combined two epistemological approaches in order to create our model since both approaches bring complementary aspects for modelling human-like behaviour.

The representational approach was useful to define the structure of the behavioural model. Our model is based on two modules. The first part uses the theories of emotions [26–32] and personality [33, 34] to produce the emotional expression of behaviour. The second module deals with social interaction. It uses theories such as emotional intelligence [26, 35, 36], communication and cognition [37–42] and social interaction [41, 43–46] to produce meaningful interactions. In order to express communication acts which transmit the intentions we used the theories of speech acts, dialogue games and nonverbal expression [38, 46–48].

Non-representational approaches were also useful to improve the behaviour of the model in terms of context dependency. In particular, ethnomethodology helped us to understand how interactions are context dependant through indexical and reflexive mechanisms.

We found that the concept of Emotional Intelligence [26, 35, 36] elaborated by Salovey and Mayer and popularised by Daniel Goleman’s 1995 book “Emotional Intelligence” assembles the emotional expression with the social interaction. This concept gives a particular importance to the expression, recognition and discrimination of one’s own and other’s feelings and emotions, which is used to guide behaviour (thinking and actions). We integrate their ideas in the behavioural model in order to create an intelligent emotional character.

We follow a cognitive approach in order to model the behaviour of the character, based on the ostensive–inferential communication theory developed by Sperber [41] and the social interaction theory of Goffman [43]. Goffman emphasise that people act as they do by the way in which they define their present situation. These arguments are in agreement and reinforce the ideas put forward by Salovey and Mayer in their concept of emotional intelligence.

In our model, the behaviour of the character is influenced by the internal state of the individual (cognitive and emotional state) and by social interaction rules. The character’s internal states (indecision or satisfaction, for example) can be expressed by the body or by gesture. It is recognised, for example that a person’s style of moving as well as face expressions offer many hints to other people about the person’s emotions or reactions [45, 48, 49]. Even if in the beginning, the expression of the emotional state is unconscious, it can also be produced intentionally to achieve a conscious goal (ostensive behaviours) [41]. For example, the intentional expression of sadness or fear could be a way to obtain assistance.

Nonverbal expressions are key elements of the human communication. They specify the realism and credibility of human behaviours. These expressions influence the credibility of speech acts [47].

An example of the complexity of the human-like behavioural expression could be found in the domain of social interaction where nonverbal expressions qualify intention depending on context and culture. Gestures can also express explicit or implicit intentions. As an example, hand movements can be intentionally used to produce a request. Conversely, head inclination can unconsciously transmit an empathic attitude towards the interlocutor.

Ethnomethodology, reflexivity and indexicality

The aim of ethnomethodology is to study, from a practical point of view, the rules of social interactions in the everyday life situations. This sociological approach states that most human expressions (words, gestures, etc.) are indexical and reflexive, this means that the local context will be a strong determinant of the semantic of the situation [50–53].

The social interaction is said to be “situated”, which means that any activity should be coupled with the social and cultural context. We take this approach of the social interaction in order to produce meaningful human interactions. Indexical expressions are used as a support for the dialogue. Whenever the pragmatic context changes, the meaning of the expression can change, because each context refers to different things, generating problems for the selection and correlation of the gestures [54].

The reflexivity is defined by Lecerf [54] as a “subjective capacity to manage the indexicality, making it possible to choose without hesitation multiple meanings that are proposed by several contextual networks”. So, the reflexivity puts in relation an indexical expression with the context.

This approach is taken into account for the nonverbal production of the dialogue; in particular, for the management of turn-taking, as well as to express the role of the gestures and indexical expressions.

Virtual session design

We have developed a virtual simulation environment for providing therapy to the rehabilitation of the active extension of the wrist to brain injured people caused by cerebral vascular accidents.

The virtual session is a triadic situation (see Fig. 2), where the patient sees at the same time his clone’s arms and the virtual therapist (autonomous character). The patient’s real arms are hidden. The patient receives instructions concerning the exercise from the virtual therapist and he can then visualise his clone’s arms carrying out a gesture in the virtual session.

The animation of the virtual therapist is based on the experimental protocol as well as the actions and attitude of the character that represent the patient. The activity of the virtual therapist consists of guiding the patient in his exercises and encouraging and correcting him. The animation of the therapist takes into account an emotional and intentional model of the patient—therapist relationship. For example, according to the course of the session, the therapist could be neutral or empathic, directing or suggestive, attentive or detached, etc.

There are two protocols for the session that the real therapist could select: “real feedback” protocol or “improved” protocol. According to the protocol, the movements of the patient will either be reproduced exactly in the virtual session (the patient will see his hand moving as in reality) or artificially amplified (“improved” protocol).

With the improved protocol the patient sees a gesture that he himself cannot do (application of the therapeutic paradigm based on mirror neuron concept). The idea behind this approach is that the perception of his ‘false’ movements activates gradually the motor circuits associated with the production of real movements.

This kind of application makes it possible to create an interactive environment, where the exercises can be controlled, quantified and modulated in order to adapt the rehabilitation according to the patient. The hope is that the patient improves his recovery, based on the “mirror neurons” therapeutic paradigm and by the generation of a social and emotional immersion produced by the interaction with the virtual character.

An example of the virtual session with an improved protocol is:

Virtual therapist::

“Let’s try this movement with your right hand”

Patient::

Produces a fluent movement. The virtual reality system mimics the same hand movement in real time.

Virtual therapist::

“Very well... let’s make the same thing with the left hand”

Patient::

Produces a low amplitude movement. The virtual reality system makes an extended movement of the left hand.

Virtual therapist::

Encourages the patient. “Well, still, still, it is well”

As we can see in this example, the virtual system amplifies the patient’s real movement inducing a false perception that may reactivate new neuromotor pathways.

Animation architecture and behaviour dynamic

The architecture for the animation of virtual characters proposes a model to generate emotional and interaction behaviours. These behaviours are produced by communication acts that transmit intentions as well as by animations that characterise emotional expressions and social interactions rules.

The architecture (see Fig. 3) generates the behaviour of the virtual characters according to the session’s protocol, a behavioural model and a kinesics model.

In order to produce credible social interactions, we started from a field analysis (ethnomethodological approach) of the rehabilitation sessions. This analysis helped us to structure and formalise the behaviour model. The following steps have been followed:

  1. 1.

    Video analysis of the rehabilitation sessions.

  • (a) Discourse analysis of patient and therapist during usual.

  • (b) Analysis of communication expressions like gestures, body movements and paraverbal activities (tone, pitch and pace of the voice).

  • (c) Analysis of the social interactions rules.

  1. 2.

    Identification of cultural differences in the expression of social interactions rules.

  2. 3.

    Design of a dialogue model to select the objectives and intentions of the therapist.

  3. 4.

    Definition of the relationship among intentions, personality and the emotional state.

  4. 5.

    Design of a model for the update of attitude.

  5. 6.

    Gesture and facial expression of the attitude.

The behavioural model is influenced by (1) the profile and internal state of the character, (2) the perception and interpretation of the context and (3) a model of socio-cultural interactions.

Context and management of the dialogue

A module called perception and interpretation evaluates the situation and in particular the actions and attitudes of the interlocutor (see Fig. 3). This module filters and appraises the information related to the cognitive context of the situation and carries out six levels of the appraisal process of the character (see Fig. 4).

This module is also in charge of the recognition of the physical context as well as the internal states of the character and their interlocutor (emotional, cognitive, empathy, mood and level of stress). The module is influenced by the model of socio-cultural interactions and defines the weight of the internal states of the character in the behaviour.

The appraisal process related to the character is based on Scherer’s appraisal-driven processes for motor expression [30]. Its goal is to control the social and emotional interactions. We incorporate a sixth level of appraisal (social appraisal) which is influenced by the profile of the character in order to integrate the concept of emotional intelligence (see Fig. 4).

The dialogue management model (see Fig. 3) is a cognitive–emotional model for the selection of the communication acts. The model applies the concept of emotional intelligence to the speech act theories in order to update the character’s goals and to decide the emotional expression (speech act and nonverbal expression) whose intention reinforces the objective.

This model has three functions: (1) management of the turn-taking dynamics, (2) updates of the objective (e.g. to guide, to correct or to encourage) and (3) the management of the dialogue stages.

The dialogue management element also models the dynamics of the intentions in order to express the objective; in other words, the intention with which the objective will be expressed (e.g. to order or to inform in order to guide the patient).

The speech acts are defined by six attributes in order to allow their selection:

  1. 1.

    The name of the dialogue game to which it belongs.

  2. 2.

    The stages of the dialogue: beginning, turn-taking or end.

  3. 3.

    The priority sequence.

  4. 4.

    The associated objective (classification by perlocutionary acts).

  5. 5.

    The associated intention (classification by illocutionary acts).

  6. 6.

    The attitude (neutral, emphatic, directive).

The selection of a speech act for a particular dialogue game depends on the current state of:

  1. 1.

    The dialogue stage of the conversation.

  2. 2.

    The objective of the character.

  3. 3.

    The intention selected to achieve the objective.

  4. 4.

    The attitude of the character.

Once the speech act is expressed, an evaluation of the patient’s actions is made in order to update the objective and intention of the character as well as to update their internal state (emotional, cognitive, empathy, mood and level of stress).

The models to update the character’s objective as well as to manage the turn-taking dynamics are the product of the video analysis of the rehabilitation sessions.

The update of the character’s internal state is made by the model of social and emotional interactions.

Social and emotional interaction model

The model of social and emotional interaction defines the expression of the behaviour dynamics in a “situated face-to-face interaction”.

The output of the model is the character’s attitude. We define the character’s attitude by four components: (1) the five-factor model of personality: openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, neuroticism; (2) the empathy level; (3) the stress level and (4) the mood.

The update processes of the attitude generate the dynamics of the behaviour, which is based on a multidimensional relationship of the following points:

  • The affective states influence the social interaction as well as the emotional behaviour. These elements evolve depending on the context.

  • The socio-cultural parameters (personality, culture, gender and rules of social interaction) influence the character behaviour (e.g. type of gesture, amplitude).

The character’s attitude could also be updated if the character has a high level of emotional intelligence and he accumulates from the interlocutor a sequence of negative evaluations.

The model integrates the characteristics of the human being that play an important part in determining the gestures. It uses the internal states of the character for the selection of the behaviour and their profile in the process of adaptation and regulation of the expression of behaviour (see Fig. 4).

These processes define the model of social and emotional interactions and are made through three sub-models: empathy model, emotional model and cognitive model (see Fig. 3).

The emotional model determines and updates the emotional state of the character (basic emotions such as joy, sadness, fear and anger), his mood and his level of stress. We propose a representation of the emotional state (see Fig. 5) based on a blend of the emotional theories of Russell, Schwartz/Shaver and Woodworth/Scholosberg [27, 29] and a relationship between Goldberg and Costa/McCrae personality models [33, 34].

The representation of the emotional state is based on four factors: stress, arousal, stance and valence. Their update is based on a relationship with the five dimensions of personality: openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness and neuroticism.

The five dimensions of personality are used to define the tendencies of the mood and the level of stress as well as to create a relationship between attitude and intentions.

The information produced by the emotional model is used in the empathy and cognitive model. The empathy model determines and updates the level of empathy, valence and the proxemic of the social interaction. The cognitive model determines the expression of the mental activity and updates the stance.

Mechanism for the selection of the animations

To produce the animations of the motor expression we follow the appraisal-driven processes based on the multi-level theory of Scherer, which models the processes of motor expression and physiological reaction patterns as well as the influence of the social identity in the intensity of the emotions [30, 32, 55].

The animation selection uses the behavioural model, particularly attitude, which is a product of the social and emotional interaction model as well as the expression of the communication act which is a result of the dialogue model.

The kinesics model selects and integrates the gestures, the facial expressions and body expressions associated with the dialogue, emotion, empathy and cognitive models to obtain the expression of the attitude selected by the behavioural model. This is necessary because the emotional and empathy models have facial and body expressions as well as the cognitive and dialogue model have gestures, facial expressions and body movements.

The final expression is then transmitted to VirtoolsFootnote 2 (a 3D game engine).

Conclusions

In the paper, we introduced the notion of “intelligent emotional character” and social immersion. We developed a model and proposed an architecture that allows verbal and paraverbal interactions between a virtual character and a human being. We used this architecture in order to assess a virtual therapy with patients suffering from brain damage and more particularly following a brain stroke. In collaboration with INSERM’s research lab, we plan to assess this technology in the context of the mirror neuron paradigm which focuses on the positive effect of the visualisation of virtual body movements that the patient is unable to produce. We discuss the advantages of using an emotional virtual character and produce situated interaction (an interaction which is both context dependant and where the human and the virtual character are tightly coupled in their mutual communications).
